awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase II:  Spatially controlled direct transfer printing of semiconductor components for high-performance flexible electronic devices
awd_abstract_narration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project will advance a novel probe-based direct transfer (PBDT) printing technology for manufacturing flexible hybrid electronic (FHE) devices. PBDT promises to deliver unprecedented selective, high-fidelity component transfer of a broad range of low-dimensional, high-performance electronic components with diverse architectures and sizes to flexible substrates. The technology will accelerate manufacturing capability to meet a critical need in the flexible and printed electronics market. The development of a stand-alone, automatic PBDT tool will provide flexible electronics developers and manufacturers an unparalleled solution for integrating high-performance thin and ultra-thin electronic materials into next-generation flexible devices. The impact on the market and on daily life has the potential to be transformative, with everything from consumer devices (e.g., flexible phones and tablets), to imaging and sensing, to health care and homeland security being improved by advancements in flexible device manufacturing. Furthermore, PBDT will enable new directions in flexible device research and product development. 

 The overall objective of the Phase II project is to produce a prototype of a commercial version of a PBDT tool. In addition, detailed performance specs of the process and tool will be established, and functional FHE devices will be assembled using automated PBDT printing. The Phase I feasibility study demonstrated that the PBDT approach of handling a flexible substrate as both a stamp and as the destination substrate allows for defect-free transfer of semiconductor components that are an order of magnitude thinner and more complex laterally than what conventional tools can handle. Based on the Phase I accomplishments, Phase II funding will be used to develop and demonstrate a prototype tool that will serve as the template for a fully automated commercial product. Successful commercialization of PBDT will require advances in PBDT processes and hardware; therefore, the specific objectives of the Phase II project are focused on (i) characterizing the full process space of PBDT technology, (ii) demonstrating a complete process flow for assembling and metalizing functional FHE devices, and (iii) validating the prototype in terms of printing rate and fidelity. The collaborating university partner will contribute to the design and fabrication of thin and ultra-thin silicon components to assess the performance of the tool and demonstrate viable FHE sensors.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Flexible and stretchable electronics technology provides the opportunity for compact, lightweight, and conformable electronic devices with applications that include healthcare, transportation, defense, and the internet of things (IoT).  Flexible hybrid electronic (FHE) devices are a particular class of flexible devices in which thin, high-performance semiconductor materials and integrated circuits are integrated onto flexible substrates with printed components to realize flexible devices with exceptional performance.  Companies and researchers across the world are developing FHE devices for a broad range of applications, but successful commercialization and deployment of these technologies will only be realized if high-yield and robust FHE manufacturing processes are available. Over the course of this STTR project, systeMECH, Inc advanced a unique process for transferring ultrathin semiconductor chips, known as direct die placement (DDP) technology, to manufacture FHE devices

 

DDP technology exploits the flexibility of thin, polymeric substrates to realize the direct transfer of chips from a source to a destination substrate. By eliminating the use of an intermediate stamp or end effector, the DDP process allows for high yield transfer of chips with a wide range of thicknesses and lateral dimensions.  Through this project we advanced our understanding of FHE devices and the DDP process through modeling and experiments.  DDP manufacturing trials with semiconductor elements ranging in thickness from 300 nanometers to 50 micrometers demonstrated the versatility of the technique and provided crucial data for demonstrating the value proposition of the technology to potential customers.  DDP manufacturing tool design was advanced, and tools for different research and manufacturing environments were designed as part of this project. Key DDP processes and tool capabilities were demonstrated through collaborative activities with Nextflex, a Manufacturing USA institute, and potential customers.

 


Last Modified: 01/13/2022
Modified by: David S Grierson
